content: hey guys DM Scotty here welcome to the crowd today I want to talk about their
Ashley key cabinets they're so fine you can do funny voices and they died in
horrible amusing ways they're just fun to play with in your games but today I'm
not going to talk about living goblins I was talking about dead goblins I had a
game where I wanted to have some or main Goblin remains like skeletal remains to
kind of freak you out the players because it's like this goblin area
big-goblin warren area so I thought it'd be fun to make some skeletons but
they're they're hard to find and I what I did was I just took some regular human
sized skeletons and then use them to make goblin skeletons so let's go to the
table I'll show you how I did that you
the first material I'm going to use are these washers and these are just steel
one inch with a quarter inch hole in the center and I really like these with a
small hole because they're they're very easy to cover up
I'm also going to use some of my favorite crafting material you guys have
seen me use this before the flexible modeling paste so I'm going to take a
scoop of this with us with a popsicle stick and apply it to the washer and
then just kind of smooth it out on top of the washer covering that hole and
that'll give me a nice base to apply the skeleton to
now last but not least you're gonna need some skeletons and since I didn't have
goblin skeletons I was converting regular human sized skeletons to goblins
so I have this set of skeleton lawyers that I got from Morgan's Factory and
these are really nice you can use these to decorate all kinds of stuff I did a
pile with these a pile of ash from my zombie game with these and so these
these are some really nice decorations so if you're not going to use them for
you know use them for their figures themselves
you can either good they're great for decorations so I would highly recommend
getting these so here you can see I've applied the
skeletons to the bases or to the washers and let me talk about this so like I
said I use the washer I applied the flexible modeling paste then I just
smushed these skeletal pieces into the flexible modeling paste but I didn't
just take the skeletal pieces from the sprues and just push a min I did some
modification so you know of course goblins are much shorter than than
regular humans so what I did was when I put when I applied these I cut the spine
that leads to the the pelvic bone I cut that off so it was much shorter I also
did virtually no neck for the the head and goblins seem to have a large head so
that that works ok there there's two different skulls here one was from the
set itself it was like a demonic skull and that worked well I just cut the
horns off of it and then the other one was a skull a had from my bits box so I
used that and it has some pointy teeth and stuff so that worked out nice for a
goblin now when I applied the arms and legs I cut the ends the the arms had a
ball that would fit into the into the model joint so I cut the end of those
off so if the arms and legs would be shorter and that seemed to work really
well for reducing the height of the miniature I also when I put the feet on
I cut the ball off the foot so that the feet were actually smaller than they
would be for a human foot so I think that worked out nicely and these so
these are all ready to go I'm just gonna let these dry and I'll paint them up so
the next I'm going to go to the to a cave setting I have and I'll show you
what they look like when they're all finished and painted oh one last thing -
when I do this stuff I like to apply a coat of PB PVA glue to help adhere the
material to this the base so it's it's not a step you necessarily have to tape
but it's just that little extra bit that if you if you put the glue on and you
just brush it on it'll dry very thinly and it won't
fact the detail of the manager so that that helps to just adhere the miniature
to the base so that's one last thing I do with this so let's now let's go to
the cave and I'll show you what they look like
so here guys I have an ice cave section and our TripIt adventurers are exploring
and one thing I want to note I want to note too that if you notice the floor I
did a little more of a rough texture on the floor by dragging the glue gun on
the floor it gives it it's still relatively flat but it gives it kind of
a nice texture that it's not a smooth floor like you might have in a crafted
dungeon so I kind of like that effect but anyways the party moves further in
and they're kind of being careful and the party that point at the party the
warrior comes around this stone here the slag mite and sees a goblin skeleton
there behind the behind the rocks so they're all on guard getting their
weapons ready checking around checking their area they come a little further in
and behind this this one here they see another goblin skillet so yeah it's not
looking good something in here has been either eating goblins or killing them so
you know the party's very much on guard so those are those are really nice they
give a nice ambience to the setting you're going to be a closer look at that
so here's the one I did he's I like him and he's kind of ass up in the air there
and for those of you who aren't familiar with the skeleton painting technique I
basically just spray it black then paint it a dark brown and then I'll dry brush
the skeleton like a an off-white and then I use a kind of a golden brown to
give it like aged and then I'll fill it out with maybe a little more dark brown
and black washes and that's really all there is to it so there you go you can
see him there I'll give you another look at the there for their skeleton here so
yeah I think these came out really nice and the washers really give them weight
so they they stay they stay in place they don't they don't
move around that's that's really nice so there we go it's some nice little Goblin
remains that you can creep out your players with and I'll see you next time
